title: US Offers $1B in Funding to Scale Critical Mineral Supply Chains
description: The US Department of Energy intends to offer funding opportunities totaling nearly $1 billion “to advance and scale mining, processing, and manufacturing technologies across key stages of the critical minerals and materials supply chains,” it says in a statement. The funding would accelerate the US critical minerals and materials sector and reduce reliance on foreign suppliers, according to officials. Factorial CEO Siyu Huang joins Bloomberg Businessweek Daily to discuss rare earth mineral supply chains, the company's Mercedes partnership, solid state battery manufacturing, and more. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: US has offered $1B in funding to scale critical mineral supply chains, including lithium, cobalt and nickel, which are critical for lithium ion batteries but are transition metals. The company has been working with direct suppliers and recycling partners, including a Korean conglomerate, South Gil, one of the largest recycling recyclers in the space, who have done a lot for the battery as well. The firm has been collaborating with automotive manufacturers, including Mercedes-Benz, Stellantis, Hyundai, and other global manufacturers. The move towards solid state batteries is part of a larger scale application that could potentially revolutionize the global supply chain. Solid state batteries, which use qualities that stay material but combine a little bit solid, liquid together, are safer, longer lasting and more powerful due to their stability and less likely to leak or catch on fire. The U.S. company has also announced partnerships with Korean companies, including South Gil and Mercedes, and has shipped thousands of batteries to their global OEM partners. They believe this will protect them from potential threats and provide a closed loop supply chain, particularly in the future of battery manufacturing.
shortSummary: The US offers $1B in funding to support solid state batteries, emphasizing their safety and durability capabilities amid global supply constraints.
argos_summary: Factorial, a company specializing in solid state batteries, is actively securing its supply chain and addressing recycling challenges associated with lithium-ion batteries. The company has partnered with major automotive manufacturers like Mercedes-Benz and Stellantis, successfully launching its first solid state battery vehicle and shipping batteries to various global partners. Factorial is also working with recycling partners to enhance battery recycling capabilities in the U.S., aiming for mass production and commercial deployment of its technology by 2027.
